par.text: Lithium is a silvery-white metal, soft enough to be cut with a knife. It is very reactive. On contact with dry air it remains unchanged, but in moist air it reacts rapidly to produce lithium hydroxide LiOH, although the reaction is not as violent as in the case of sodium (Na) and potassium (K). Lithium and its compounds impart a crimson colour to a flame. The name lithium is derived from the Greek
- ”stone”. Lithium was discovered in 1817 by a Swedish chemist,
Johan August Arfvedson. Pure lithium was first obtained by W.T. Brande and H. Davy.
